The University will launch a nine-building
long range expansion program this spring, plant
manager J. Wesley Taylor announced this week.
The nine structures are to be erected within
the next 25 years, adding 700,000 square feet
of space to the Homewood campus's present
plant of 1,400,000 square feet.

JHU Magazine Sets
New Topical Format
By DAVID SCHNEIDERMAN
The Johns Hopkins Magazine,
long regarded as one of the finest
alumni magazines in the country,
is undergoing significant changes
in content and purpose.
Tony Neville, editor of the Magazine, has announced that as of
winter '66 The Johns Hopkins
Magazine will be• published on a
of
instead
basis
quarterly
monthly.
More important, however, is
the new policy of devoting each
issue • to one specific topic of
broad interest and eliminating
"alumni news."
The alumni will not be forgotten since a new publication, The
Johns Hopkins Journal, to be
published six times a year, will
be devoted entirely to news of
Hopkins alumni. It will be edited
by the Office of Institutional Public Relations.
Revamping Magazine
The decision to revamp Time
Johns Hopkins Magazine stems
from Mr. Neville's desire to provide the Hopkins alumni with a
"continuing education," He said
that "we are concerned with matters of interest to readers as citizens, not just alumni. We always
found in the past that we had
greatest effect when we devoted
an issue to a specific subject."

Mr. Neville then produced a large
stock of letters to support his
statement.
In the past twelve months, The
Johns Hopkins Magazine has published two pilot issues. The Octo

Offices Moved
The building is expected to
contain 50,000 square feet of

The Plant Manager's offices in

The original plan for the

area," Taylor commented.
However, he asserted that the
new style will harmonize with
the red brick and white trim of
the old.

the relocation of the four Levering Field tennis courts. Two

Advanced Drop Date Furthers
More Mature Academic Outlook
Undergraduates wishing to
drop courses yet this semester
must secure the approval of Dean
William Kelso Morrill or Dean
Carl P. Swanson. Freshmen must
see Dean Morrill while all others
must talk to Dean Swanson.
In the past, reported Dean
Swanson, the drop date was set
unreasonably late, usually in the
twelfth week. The deadline for
dropping courses with the ndvisor's approval this semester
was moved up to October 26.
According to Swanson, the student who drops a course to avoid
a low grade is doing a disservice
to those who do not. Students
who find themselves on the borderline grade-wise are handicapped more when a number of
students with lower marks drop
out.

It is erroneous to relate the
drop date and grades, added
Swanson. The attitude of the
school, he continued, is that the
drop date should not be the determining factor when a student
plans his schedule. The importance of grades should be deemphasized.
"We want to develop a more
mature student attitude toward
course selection so that courses
won't be chosen because of possible grades." Swanson added.
"Moving up the drop date forces
the student to think more before selecting courses."
This decision in no way affects
the student's chances of picking
up new courses later in the semester. A student can pick up a
course at any time pending the
professor's approval.

The Graduate Club has arranged with Paul Masson of California to sponsor a wine education and tasting night.
This event highlights the Club's
introduction of Paul Masson
wines to its bill-of-fare. A general discussion by Richard Levi
will include; American and foreign wines, classes of wines,
cooking wine, and premium
wines.
Those thirsting after more than
just knowledge may avail themselves of free samples, including
some of America's rare sherries.
The whole event gets off the
ground at 8:30 p.m. in McCoy
Hall Lobby.
Hostesses for the event will be
senior nurses from the JHU
School of Nursing. Membership
in the Graduate Club is open
to all graduate and post-graduate
students over 21. Membership
forms are available at the club
room, McCoy Hall.

Hop Prof.
Endorses
Art Loan
Among the questions on the
November 8th ballot in Baltimore city will be that of the
Walters Art Gallery Loan.
Located at Charles and Centre
Streets on Washington Square,
the Walters Art Gallery was
built in 1908 to contain the collection of Henry Walters, and
was at that time barely adequate.
From then until his death, Henry
Walters continued to collect in
such great volume that, today
75% of his collection remains
in storage for want of display
space. The Gallery was deeded
to the city upon his death in1931.
The question calls for a bond
issue to match a State Assembly
grant of $1 million. Contributions of $2 million have already
been promised by interested citizens, making a total of $4 million. The state grant, and many
of the private pledges, are contingent on the passage of the
bond issue.
In an. interview for the News
Letter, Dr. H. T. Rowell, professor of Classics, stated that the
Walters has one of the finest
collections of art of classical antiquity in existence. It is extremely valuable to students of
archaeology, and Doctor Rowell
mentioned that there have always been close relations between the curator, Dr. Dorothy
Hill, herself a Hopkins Ph.D.,
and the University. Dr. Rowell
strongly urged the passage of the
loan, and expressed his optimism
of its chances.

"The addition of two courts
there will give the Athletic Department the required number
for varsity play," Taylor noted.
The site of the second two courts
is undetermined.
Plans also call for the road
between the Aeronautics Building
and Levering Hall to be turned
West into San Martin Drive.
With the start of construction,
President Eisenhower's recently
imposed ten-year moratorium on
building will be lifted.
"The President thought we had
reached a plateau," Taylor explained, "but there is already a
demand for more space."

ber '65 issue was devoted to

The News-Letter will issue no warnings or incriminations regarding the value of a free press this week.
We wish to make it clear to everyone involved that the
most valuable action imaginable would be to underline
the most spectacularly absurd Administrative Circus in
recent memory.
We refer, of course, to the pathetic machinations,
repercussions and controversy that surrounded the publication of a feature article on sex that appeared in last
weeks issue of what was formally the innocent, incompetent, bungling but lovable Goucher Weekly.
We congratulate the Weekly for arousing (abet
unintentionally) the foolish ire of half the good ladies
of Goucher College. It was, naturally, a great pity that
the vehicle chosen (the actual article) was a tasteless
and largely uninformative commentary on the Towson

Kudos to Reborn Barnstormers
By GERALD BRECHER
Well, it certainly is nice to find
out that the Barnstormers actually still exist. What with Ed
Golden and company monopolizng the Barn for the past year,
and what seems to have been a
substantial cut in the Barnstormers' share of the Student
Activity budget, the Barnstormers seemed to sort of roll over
and if not die, then at least remain comatose.
No one ever would have
dreamed of terming the Barnstormers truly excellent. But it is
a troupe of enthusiastic undergraduates who in the past have
put on some supremely competent and at times dazzling performances. In recent years those
that come to mind especially are
J.B., Rashomon, and the first
Barnstormer musical ever, The
Fantasticks.
The Barnstormers date back
over thirty years and were widely
known in Baltimore in their early days. Today we have Theatre
Hopkins and pretty good nonprofessional theatre and what
has seemed to be an almost total anemia with regard to the
undergraduate theatre.
This past weekend however
the Barnstormers showed some
life. Two one-act plays, produced
by senior Dave Ricci, an active
Barnstormer for four years, were
presented Saturday and Sunday
evenings. The first, A. A. Milne's
The Ugly Duckling, directed by
Jack Teider, was a delightful performance of this adaptation of
the old fairy tale by the author
of Winnie the Pooh. The staging
and costuming were sort of bizarre—on the order of low camp
perhaps—but the acting was a
sheer joy.
Vinee Millard was properly regal as the king (if anyone could
possibly be regal dressed like
that!) and played the role with
an almost professional 'majesty.

version of libido.
But if you will allow, we will also take this opportunity to congratulate ourselves on getting in on the
fun and perhaps proving once and for all the preservation of a sense of folly is the profoundest insurance
against such a sad loss of emotional perspective and
critical proportion.
The News-Letter apologizes to all Hopkins for bowing to the administrations of both institutions and not
reprinting the article as we had originally planned. We
urge you find what is by now a collectors item, certainly
a journalistic curiosity, and insert it in the blank space
on page five.
We shall only employ in our defense the words of
Willie Davis to Sandy Koufax: "The suns not yellow,
it's chicken "

Open Door Policy
The decision of the Administration to permit girls
in the freshman dormitories is one which we heartily
support. Hopefully, it is indicative of an increased University concern for the extra-academic problems confronting those living on campus.
To a great extent, the responsibility for further
change lies with the freshmen themselves. Abuse of the
privilege can only reinforce the Administration's faith in
the status quo and undo whatever progress is being
made.
The hours that have been set up, namely from noon
to 1 a.m., are liberal indeed, with the credit for their
establishment going to Colonel Serena. If the plan does
prove to be practicable, we see no reason why the visiting privileges should not be extended to include Friday
evening and all day Sunday.

Athata,
Chicken Coop
In recent weeks the words substantal profits, cooperative and
boycott have received considerable attention. Unfortunately,
the student body as a whole
knows very little about these
words. For example, very few
Freshmen know that the bookstore, dormitories, dining hall,
cafeteria, and snack bar are all
run by the plant manager's office
and not by a private business
concern. Most students are well
aware that the bookstore operates at a substantial profit, but
very few students are aware that
the dining hall operates at a
substantial Wes. The money from
all of these enterprises is put
together in one plant manager's
budget, which operates just a
little bit in the black. One enterprise's losses are made up by
another one's profits. If the
bookstore's profits were removed
from the plant manager's budget, more money would have to
come in from one of the other
enterprises. Thus by lowering the
price of books, the price of tuition, room or board could conceivably go up. It is however, unfair that all of the students
should pay high book prices so
that the plant manager can effectively subsidize the dining hall
for the benefit of the students
living on campus. The bookstore
should not operate at a profit,
nor should the dining hall operate at a loss.
Many students signed a petir
Mon urging that the bookstore

be removed entirely from the
plant manager's office and reestablished as a cooperative. A
cooperative will, however, place
an extremely heavy burden on
the students who have to run
it. How many students who
signed the petition are really
willing to devote the time and
work necessary to insure proper
management of the student coopertive?
It is my opinion that the administration does not have to be
intimidated by the threat of a
boycott to correct the faults and
do what is fair with regard to
the bookstore.
Bill LaCorte, '70

To the Editors:
I was annoyed by the article
"Election Results Predicted to
Maintain Trends" in the October 28 isue of the News-Letter.
The source of my annoyance was
Mr. Lebar's attempt to downgrade the Democratic Party and
to raise his precious Republican
Party to the lvvel of a deity. Mr.
Lebar's procedure in doing this
was obvious. He simply pointed
to all the Southern Democratic
bigots such as George Wallace
and Lester Maddox, who disown
the national party most of the
time, and George Mahoney, who
the national party has disowned.
Then he said, in so many words,
that the Democratic Party has
become the haven for bigots,
while the Republican Party consists of "tolerant" conservatives.

1

But what about all those Democratic liberals he mentioned, but
so lightly passed over in his
article? As a former resident of
Massachusetts, I am appalled to
see the name of Endicott Peabody linked to ,the intelligence
and the beliefs of men like Lester
Maddox. Mr. Peabody is a true
liberal, following the same precepts as men like John F. Kennedy. As a leader he has been
outspoken on all the major issues
from civil rights to Viet Nam,
always supporting the liberal
cause. He comes from a family
of liberal thinking people, emphasized last year when his
mother was arrested in the south
while taking part in a civil rights
demonstration. As a governor,
Peabody pushed through more
worthwhile legislation than any
governor in recent history.
Among his successes were the
curbing of the power of the
pesky governor's council, which
used to have vote power over
the governor, and the lengthening of the governor's term from
2 to 4 years. Both measures were
long awaited. Now let us examine
Mr. Peabody's opponent for Senator, Edward Brooke, to whom
Mr. Lebar brought special attention because Brooke is a Negro.
Brooke has been Attorney General of Massachusetts for four
years and he has done a "good"
job. However, during this period
of four years, Brooke has introduced very few, if any, bills and
has not been outspoken on any

changes in the constitution.

Student Council President to
be either a junior or senior,
instead of only a senior.

making three representatives
and the president from each
class.

second in the overall event and
first in the fraternities. The
other two finishers for Phi Sig
were Larry Lewis and Brian
Berke. Taking a second in the
fraternity event was Phi Gamma

The nine structures are to be erected within
the next 25 years, adding 700,000 square feet
of space to the Homewood campus's present
plant of 1,400,000 square feet.

JHU Magazine Sets
New Topical Format
By DAVID SCHNEIDERMAN
The Johns Hopkins Magazine,
long regarded as one of the finest
alumni magazines in the country,
is undergoing significant changes
in content and purpose.
Tony Neville, editor of the Magazine, has announced that as of
winter '66 The Johns Hopkins
Magazine will be• published on a
of
instead
basis
quarterly
monthly.
More important, however, is
the new policy of devoting each
issue • to one specific topic of
broad interest and eliminating
"alumni news."
The alumni will not be forgotten since a new publication, The
Johns Hopkins Journal, to be
published six times a year, will
be devoted entirely to news of
Hopkins alumni. It will be edited
by the Office of Institutional Public Relations.
Revamping Magazine
The decision to revamp Time
Johns Hopkins Magazine stems
from Mr. Neville's desire to provide the Hopkins alumni with a
"continuing education," He said
that "we are concerned with matters of interest to readers as citizens, not just alumni. We always
found in the past that we had
greatest effect when we devoted
an issue to a specific subject."

Mr. Neville then produced a large
stock of letters to support his
statement.

Offices Moved
The building is expected to

The Plant Manager's offices in

style if we developed a new
area," Taylor commented.
However, he asserted that the
new style will harmonize with
the red brick and white trim of
the old.

Advanced Drop Date Furthers
More Mature Academic Outlook
Undergraduates wishing to
drop courses yet this semester
must secure the approval of Dean
William Kelso Morrill or Dean
Carl P. Swanson. Freshmen must
see Dean Morrill while all others
must talk to Dean Swanson.
In the past, reported Dean
Swanson, the drop date was set
unreasonably late, usually in the
twelfth week. The deadline for
dropping courses with the ndvisor's approval this semester
was moved up to October 26.
According to Swanson, the student who drops a course to avoid
a low grade is doing a disservice
to those who do not. Students
who find themselves on the borderline grade-wise are handicapped more when a number of
students with lower marks drop
out.

It is erroneous to relate the
drop date and grades, added
Swanson. The attitude of the
school, he continued, is that the
drop date should not be the determining factor when a student
plans his schedule. The importance of grades should be deemphasized.
"We want to develop a more
mature student attitude toward
course selection so that courses
won't be chosen because of possible grades." Swanson added.
"Moving up the drop date forces
the student to think more before selecting courses."
This decision in no way affects
the student's chances of picking
up new courses later in the semester. A student can pick up a
course at any time pending the
professor's approval.

The Graduate Club has arranged with Paul Masson of California to sponsor a wine education and tasting night.
This event highlights the Club's
introduction of Paul Masson
wines to its bill-of-fare. A general discussion by Richard Levi
will include; American and foreign wines, classes of wines,
cooking wine, and premium
wines.
Those thirsting after more than
just knowledge may avail themselves of free samples, including
some of America's rare sherries.
The whole event gets off the
ground at 8:30 p.m. in McCoy
Hall Lobby.
Hostesses for the event will be
senior nurses from the JHU
School of Nursing. Membership
in the Graduate Club is open
to all graduate and post-graduate
students over 21. Membership
forms are available at the club
room, McCoy Hall.

Hop Prof.
Endorses
Art Loan
Among the questions on the
November 8th ballot in Baltimore city will be that of the
Walters Art Gallery Loan.
Located at Charles and Centre
Streets on Washington Square,
the Walters Art Gallery was
built in 1908 to contain the collection of Henry Walters, and
was at that time barely adequate.
From then until his death, Henry
Walters continued to collect in
such great volume that, today
75% of his collection remains
in storage for want of display
space. The Gallery was deeded
to the city upon his death in1931.
The question calls for a bond
issue to match a State Assembly
grant of $1 million. Contributions of $2 million have already
been promised by interested citizens, making a total of $4 million. The state grant, and many
of the private pledges, are contingent on the passage of the
bond issue.
In an. interview for the News
Letter, Dr. H. T. Rowell, professor of Classics, stated that the
Walters has one of the finest
collections of art of classical antiquity in existence. It is extremely valuable to students of
archaeology, and Doctor Rowell
mentioned that there have always been close relations between the curator, Dr. Dorothy
Hill, herself a Hopkins Ph.D.,
and the University. Dr. Rowell
strongly urged the passage of the
loan, and expressed his optimism
of its chances.

demand for more space."

Kudos to Reborn Barnstormers
By GERALD BRECHER
Well, it certainly is nice to find
out that the Barnstormers actually still exist. What with Ed
Golden and company monopolizng the Barn for the past year,
and what seems to have been a
substantial cut in the Barnstormers' share of the Student
Activity budget, the Barnstormers seemed to sort of roll over
and if not die, then at least remain comatose.
No one ever would have
dreamed of terming the Barnstormers truly excellent. But it is
a troupe of enthusiastic undergraduates who in the past have
put on some supremely competent and at times dazzling performances. In recent years those
that come to mind especially are
J.B., Rashomon, and the first
Barnstormer musical ever, The
Fantasticks.
The Barnstormers date back
over thirty years and were widely
known in Baltimore in their early days. Today we have Theatre
Hopkins and pretty good nonprofessional theatre and what
has seemed to be an almost total anemia with regard to the
undergraduate theatre.
This past weekend however
the Barnstormers showed some
life. Two one-act plays, produced
by senior Dave Ricci, an active
Barnstormer for four years, were
presented Saturday and Sunday
evenings. The first, A. A. Milne's
The Ugly Duckling, directed by
Jack Teider, was a delightful performance of this adaptation of
the old fairy tale by the author
of Winnie the Pooh. The staging
and costuming were sort of bizarre—on the order of low camp
perhaps—but the acting was a
sheer joy.
Vinee Millard was properly regal as the king (if anyone could
possibly be regal dressed like
that!) and played the role with
an almost professional 'majesty.

version of libido.
But if you will allow, we will also take this opportunity to congratulate ourselves on getting in on the
fun and perhaps proving once and for all the preservation of a sense of folly is the profoundest insurance
against such a sad loss of emotional perspective and
critical proportion.
The News-Letter apologizes to all Hopkins for bowing to the administrations of both institutions and not
reprinting the article as we had originally planned. We
urge you find what is by now a collectors item, certainly
a journalistic curiosity, and insert it in the blank space
on page five.
We shall only employ in our defense the words of
Willie Davis to Sandy Koufax: "The suns not yellow,
it's chicken "

Open Door Policy
The decision of the Administration to permit girls
in the freshman dormitories is one which we heartily
support. Hopefully, it is indicative of an increased University concern for the extra-academic problems confronting those living on campus.
To a great extent, the responsibility for further
change lies with the freshmen themselves. Abuse of the
privilege can only reinforce the Administration's faith in
the status quo and undo whatever progress is being
made.
The hours that have been set up, namely from noon
to 1 a.m., are liberal indeed, with the credit for their
establishment going to Colonel Serena. If the plan does
prove to be practicable, we see no reason why the visiting privileges should not be extended to include Friday
evening and all day Sunday.

Athata,
Chicken Coop
In recent weeks the words substantal profits, cooperative and
boycott have received considerable attention. Unfortunately,
the student body as a whole
knows very little about these
words. For example, very few
Freshmen know that the bookstore, dormitories, dining hall,
cafeteria, and snack bar are all
run by the plant manager's office
and not by a private business
concern. Most students are well
aware that the bookstore operates at a substantial profit, but
very few students are aware that
the dining hall operates at a
substantial Wes. The money from
all of these enterprises is put
together in one plant manager's
budget, which operates just a
little bit in the black. One enterprise's losses are made up by
another one's profits. If the
bookstore's profits were removed
from the plant manager's budget, more money would have to
come in from one of the other
enterprises. Thus by lowering the
price of books, the price of tuition, room or board could conceivably go up. It is however, unfair that all of the students
should pay high book prices so
that the plant manager can effectively subsidize the dining hall
for the benefit of the students
living on campus. The bookstore
should not operate at a profit,
nor should the dining hall operate at a loss.
Many students signed a petir
Mon urging that the bookstore

be removed entirely from the
plant manager's office and reestablished as a cooperative. A
cooperative will, however, place
an extremely heavy burden on
the students who have to run
it. How many students who
signed the petition are really
willing to devote the time and
work necessary to insure proper
management of the student coopertive?
It is my opinion that the administration does not have to be
intimidated by the threat of a
boycott to correct the faults and
do what is fair with regard to
the bookstore.
Bill LaCorte, '70

To the Editors:
I was annoyed by the article
"Election Results Predicted to
Maintain Trends" in the October 28 isue of the News-Letter.
The source of my annoyance was
Mr. Lebar's attempt to downgrade the Democratic Party and
to raise his precious Republican
Party to the lvvel of a deity. Mr.
Lebar's procedure in doing this
was obvious. He simply pointed
to all the Southern Democratic
bigots such as George Wallace
and Lester Maddox, who disown
the national party most of the
time, and George Mahoney, who
the national party has disowned.
Then he said, in so many words,
that the Democratic Party has
become the haven for bigots,
while the Republican Party consists of "tolerant" conservatives.

1

But what about all those Democratic liberals he mentioned, but
so lightly passed over in his
article? As a former resident of
Massachusetts, I am appalled to
see the name of Endicott Peabody linked to ,the intelligence
and the beliefs of men like Lester
Maddox. Mr. Peabody is a true
liberal, following the same precepts as men like John F. Kennedy. As a leader he has been
outspoken on all the major issues
from civil rights to Viet Nam,
always supporting the liberal
cause. He comes from a family
of liberal thinking people, emphasized last year when his
mother was arrested in the south
while taking part in a civil rights
demonstration. As a governor,
Peabody pushed through more
worthwhile legislation than any
governor in recent history.
Among his successes were the
curbing of the power of the
pesky governor's council, which
used to have vote power over
the governor, and the lengthening of the governor's term from
2 to 4 years. Both measures were
long awaited. Now let us examine
Mr. Peabody's opponent for Senator, Edward Brooke, to whom
Mr. Lebar brought special attention because Brooke is a Negro.
Brooke has been Attorney General of Massachusetts for four
years and he has done a "good"
job. However, during this period
of four years, Brooke has introduced very few, if any, bills and
has not been outspoken on any

Frustrated Jays
Face Washington
(Continued from Page 8)
are 1-3-1 on the season, and
have managed to score only six
goals. They are not the strong,
powerhouse team they have been
in the past since they were hit
hard by graduation, especially in
the defensive unit.
Last year the Shoremen defeated Hopkins 3-0, but only part
of that line and the goalie are
returning. Ed Winant and Bob
Checket are the leaders for Washington. Checket is from Baltimore where he attended Milford
Mill High School. The Shoremen's goalie, Al Perry, was an
all - Mason - Dixon Conference
pick last year. The 6-inch-three.
215 lb. goalie is joined by coicaptrain Dick Louck, an outstanding halfback.
The Bluejays have been working hard on passing drills this
week, and are looking forward to
tomorrow's game. They will have
to stop pressing for goals, since
Coach Barrette feels that they
might try too hard and feel pressured to score. He believes that
the team is still maintaining a
good mental attitude and are not
extremely let down over their
frustrating defeats. Physically
the squad is in good shape, with
only Drobney and Stu Hodgson
nursing sprained ankles.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE. NOVEMBER 4, 1966

BIA

Phi Ep Stuns Phi Sig kidders
Phi Epsilon Pi scored a stunning 9-6 win over Phi Sig in
fraternity football action Tuesday.
Quarterback Mike Marcus and
ends Bill Bonds and Rich Fox
paced the Phi Ep assault. In
Other games Tuesday, unbeaten
ATO defeated Phi Psi and TEP
downed AEPi.
In a time or 7:40 freshman
Ray Price of Gildersleeve led the
pack composed of fraternity, upperclass, and frosh competitors
in the Goucher Gallup cross
country event. Gildersleeve went
on to win the event for the
freshman houses with Jim Stewart leading Baker to a second
place. Willard house took the upperclass dorm competition.
Phi Sigma Delta, recipient of
the 1965-66 Alumni Trophy, took
first place in fraternity event.
Jeff Lauren of Phi Sig took a
second in the overall event and
first in the fraternities. The
other two finishers for Phi Sig
were Larry Lewis and Brian
Berke. Taking a second in the
fraternity event was Phi Gamma
Delta paced by Rich Dryden, P.
J. Kemiodel, and Phil Buck.

touchfootball protest was upheld
by the BIA last week. In the Phi

Psi-Phi Ep football contest, Phi
Ep, winning 7-6, was called for
offensive pass interference in the
end-zone. Phi Ep did not receive
the proper penalty for this infraction and Phi Psi protested
the game.
Because it was a referee's error,
the BIA voted to replay the
game at the point of infraction.
Phi Psi now had the ball on the
Phi Ep one-yard line with four
plays left in the game.
Phi Psi replayed this game on
Tuesday. At the end of the
fourth play the score remained
Phi Ep 7-Phi Psi 6.
Basketball entries are to be
made to Mrs. Rogers at the Athletic Center Office no later than
November 11. Officiating forfeiture fees will be carried over
from football.
